content.raw:
The same here - Option 1 error, Option 2 opens the main window.

When I do 

`$ export XAUTH=/tmp/.docker.xauth`

before running Option 1, then even Option 1 runs \(XAUTH is empty by default in my environment - ubuntu 18.04\)

```
$ docker inspect --format='{{index .RepoDigests 0}}' nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed
nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed@sha256:1145790d83973b37bd4851e6e329d24de062a99e19f898e22438c9d3882c00a6
```

…for the sha256 of the image I am running. Using

```
$ docker pull nkoenig/subt-virtual-testbed@sha256:1145790d83973b37bd4851e6e329d24de062a99e19f898e22438c9d3882c00a6
```

will give you the same image. It would be great to get some release hygiene done like using some release name/version/hash or any other unique identifier instead of tag “latest”, thanks.

issue.title: *** New SubT Simulation docker image available on DockerHub ***

content.raw:
Morning all, I think I figured out what was going on here. In the previous image, the ‘developer’ account in the docker container had a uid of 1000. On a base install of ubuntu, that’s the first user. If you happen to be logged in with a user that has that same uid on your local machine, xauth is happy and everything works.

In the ‘latest’ docker image \(sha256:1145790d83973b37bd4851e6e329d24de062a99e19f898e22438c9d3882c00a6\), the ‘developer’ account switched uids and is now 1001. As such, that user essentially fails xauth and cannot access the display.

The quick fix is to turn off auth with ‘xhost \+local:root’ - although this is a bad idea from a security standpoint. That said, running docker containers with ‘--privileged’ and ‘--security-opt seccomp=unconfined’ is also pretty terrible, so I’m not sure how much worse of a position that puts everyone in. Please don’t own all of our machines OSRF. :slight_smile:

\(Some additional details are here for those who are interested: [http://wiki.ros.org/docker/Tutorials/GUI](http://wiki.ros.org/docker/Tutorials/GUI)\)

Cheers,  
-Adam
content.html:
Morning all, I think I figured out what was going on here. In the previous image, the ‘developer’ account in the docker container had a uid of 1000. On a base install of ubuntu, that’s the first user. If you happen to be logged in with a user that has that same uid on your local machine, xauth is happy and everything works.

In the ‘latest’ docker image (sha256:1145790d83973b37bd4851e6e329d24de062a99e19f898e22438c9d3882c00a6), the ‘developer’ account switched uids and is now 1001. As such, that user essentially fails xauth and cannot access the display.

The quick fix is to turn off auth with ‘xhost +local:root’ - although this is a bad idea from a security standpoint. That said, running docker containers with ‘--privileged’ and ‘--security-opt seccomp=unconfined’ is also pretty terrible, so I’m not sure how much worse of a position that puts everyone in. Please don’t own all of our machines OSRF.

(Some additional details are here for those who are interested: http://wiki.ros.org/docker/Tutorials/GUI)

Cheers,
-Adam

issue.title: *** New SubT Simulation docker image available on DockerHub ***

content.raw:
After some testing, here are the steps to run the simulation remotely without xhost \+:

1. use ssh to connect to the server
2. export XAUTHORITY=/run/user/1000/gdm/Xauthority or the value you get from your local environment when not connected remotely
3. export DISPLAY=:0
4. ./run.bash …

If you for some reason get an unsuccessful run, don’t forget to delete the file /tmp/.docker.xauth as it contains authorization cookie which is not working for you.
content.html:
After some testing, here are the steps to run the simulation remotely without xhost +:

  1. use ssh to connect to the server
  2. export XAUTHORITY=/run/user/1000/gdm/Xauthority or the value you get from your local environment when not connected remotely
  3. export DISPLAY=:0
  4. ./run.bash …

If you for some reason get an unsuccessful run, don’t forget to delete the file /tmp/.docker.xauth as it contains authorization cookie which is not working for you.

content.raw:
Is anyone else having problems with the OGRE error again?

I am seeing this both locally and remotely, with fresh docker and nvidia-toolkit installs. I’ve also upgraded/updated all my packages, the tunnel\_circuit branch, and fuel models. Started fresh with the docker install instructions and cloudsim architecture.

I also tried Zbyněk Winkler’s solution on the remote server, and it did not help.

Local error output:

```
[Err] [Ogre2RenderEngine.cc:338] Unable to open display: :1
No protocol specified
terminate called after throwing an instance of 'Ogre::RenderingAPIException'
  what():  OGRE EXCEPTION(3:RenderingAPIException): Couldn`t open X display :1 in GLXGLSupport::getGLDisplay at /var/lib/jenkins/workspace/ogre-2.1-debbuilder/repo/RenderSystems/GL3Plus/src/windowing/GLX/OgreGLXGLSupport.cpp (line 789)
```

This is a problem for the testbed and for the cloud sim docker.

content.html:
I tried both Option 1 and Option 2 of the SystemSetupDockerhub tutorial to launch the testbed - not sure which created that image

issue.title: *** New SubT Simulation docker image available on DockerHub ***

content.raw:
Please remove it and then launch it docker image using the `run.bash` as shown below

```
$ rm -fv /tmp/.docker.xauth

$ wget #!/osrf/subt/raw/tunnel_circuit/docker/run.bash

$ ./run.bash osrf/subt-virtual-testbed tunnel_circuit_practice.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1
```
content.html:
Please remove it and then launch it docker image using the run.bash as shown below

$ rm -fv /tmp/.docker.xauth

$ wget #!/osrf/subt/raw/tunnel_circuit/docker/run.bash

$ ./run.bash osrf/subt-virtual-testbed tunnel_circuit_practice.ign robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

content.raw:
That worked locally. 

Remotely, the GUI opened briefly, then shut down with this error:

```
[GUI] [Err] [Application.cc:653] [QT] Failed to create OpenGL context for format QSurfaceFormat(version 2.0, options QFlags<QSurfaceFormat::FormatOption>(), depthBufferSize 24, redBufferSize -1, greenBufferSize -1, blueBufferSize -1, alphaBufferSize -1, stencilBufferSize 8, samples -1, swapBehavior QSurfaceFormat::SwapBehavior(DoubleBuffer), swapInterval 1, profile  QSurfaceFormat::OpenGLContextProfile(NoProfile)) 
```

Then shut down with this info:

```
X Error of failed request:  BadValue (integer parameter out of range for operation)
  Major opcode of failed request:  155 (GLX)
  Minor opcode of failed request:  3 (X_GLXCreateContext)
  Value in failed request:  0x0
  Serial number of failed request:  22
  Current serial number in output stream:  23
```
